Your feedback helps us prioritize which bugs to investigate and address first.

body:
Hey @staticf0x, the case sensitivity should only apply if you add new options (with `accept_new_options=True`). E.g. if you already have "Apple" in the list of options but you type in "apple", you can add "apple" as an additional option. 

Based on your example, it seems like you rather talk about case sensitivity when filtering existing options? That is still case insensitive (i.e. if you search for "apple", it will also show you results with "Apple", see your own screenshot). I'm currently working on a PR to add a parameter for this in #10076 but might still take a bit since I'm just doing it on the side whenever I have time. Is that what you're looking for or something else?

Hi, yes I'm talking about filtering existing options. Has something changed there as well? Because prior to 1.46.0 it would filter essentially akin to `search_string.lower() in option.lower()` but since 1.46.0 it seems to prefer options that first match the string **and** the case, followed by options that match the string, **but not** the case. My first hunch was the PR I linked but perhaps I was wrong and the cause is different.

@staticf0x Can you show a before/after example of what you are looking at? 

As Johannes mentions, the example you have here is confusing because it is actually filtering to all case insensitive options in your screenshot.

I am facing a similar issue but couldn't figure out why this bug was occurring, but I think you're right that it's with the case sensitivity. In my case as a quick example, I used to be able to type in something like "han" into st.selectbox() and the default option would be "Hannah," but the default is now an option such as "Johannah" or even "Meghan" due to the "han" similarity.

@sfc-gh-lwilby I used @JacobPilawa 's example to showcase the case sensitivity (thanks for the idea!):

**1.45.1**

Both `han` and `Han` produce the same result -> case insensitive.

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/1e4e3a42-bd79-4818-8099-27b353fe9015)

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/b528b6d5-25f8-4209-be23-ffde1318bc38)

**1.46.0**

`han` matches `Some other han` first and `Han` matches `Hannah` first -> case sensitive.

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/d7b747aa-9bb1-4b6e-a8d4-cee9a90021d1)

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/f6382cf8-3e9d-4301-991e-ab3ec196692a)


To me both versions are logical. In my apps, however, I usually have a lot of options that I filter through and I don't want to care about case. Either a simple bool flag for the selectbox to enable/disable this behavior or the #10076 approach would be good in this case.

Thanks @staticf0x , I agree both versions are logical so I don't consider this a bug. Instead, I will update the label to enhancement to add an option for users to choose case sensitive/insenstive filtering. It sounds like Johannes is already working on this ðŸ™Œ

rename.from: Select boxes are case sensitive without any option to set them to case insesitive
rename.to: selectbox and multiselect are case sensitive without any option to set them to case insesitive

issue.title: st.multiselect should be case insensitive

labels.name: type:enhancement
labels.description: Requests for feature enhancements or new features
